title: Weak Gravity Conjecture, Black Hole Entropy, and Modular Invariance
abstract:
In recent literature, it has been argued that a mild form of the Weak Gravity
Conjecture (WGC) is satisfied by wide classes of effective field theories in
which higher-derivative corrections can be shown to shift the charge-to-mass
ratios of extremal black holes to larger values. However, this mild form does
not directly constrain low-energy physics because the black holes satisfying
the WGC have masses above the cutoff of the effective theory. In this note, we
point out that in string theory modular invariance can connect a light
superextremal state to heavy superextremal states; the latter collapse into
black holes at small string coupling. In the context of heterotic string
theory, we show that these states are black holes that have $\alpha'$-exact
charge-to-mass ratios exceeding the classical extremality bound. This suggests
that modular invariance of the string partition function can be used to relate
the existence of a light superextremal particle to the positive shift in
charge-to-mass ratio of extremal black holes.
label: hep-th

title:
Quantum vs. classical information: operator negativity as a probe of
  scrambling
abstract:
We consider the logarithmic negativity and related quantities of time
evolution operators. We study free fermion, compact boson, and holographic
conformal field theories (CFTs) as well as numerical simulations of chaotic
quantum spin chains. In all of these examples, the operator negativity grows
linearly in time, a result which we argue is a generic feature of scrambling.
We also consider the operator entanglement of a_reflection_ operator. For
holographic CFTs, we find that its operator negativity is given by the area of
the minimal cross-section of the wormhole. We suggest that it can be used to
define a notion of a 'renormalized' entropy of the eternal black hole which is
finite, and agrees with the classical Bekenstein-Hawking entropy at leading
order.
label: hep-th

title: A new class of COM-Poisson regression models with applications
abstract:
The Conway-Maxwell-Poisson (CMP) distribution is a flexible alternative to
the Poisson distribution for modeling count data, as it allows for both
over-dispersion and under-dispersion. However, its use has been limited due to
the complexity of its normalizing constant. We propose a new class of CMP
regression models with a new link function. We show how to fit this model via
maximum likelihood by simply using an offset. We develop a CMP regression based
on iterative reweighed least squares (IRLS) and then extend this model to allow
for additive components using a penalized splines approach. Because the CMP
distribution belongs to the exponential family, convergence of IRLS is
guaranteed under some regularity conditions. Further, it is also known that
IRLS provides smaller standard errors compared to gradient-based methods. We
illustrate the usefulness of this approach through extensive simulation studies
and using real data from a bike sharing system in Washington, DC.
label: stat

title:
algcomparison: Comparing the Performance of Graphical Structure Learning
  Algorithms with TETRAD
abstract:
In this report we describe a tool for comparing the performance of graphical
causal structure learning algorithms implemented in the TETRAD freeware suite
of causal analysis methods. Currently the tool is available as package in the
TETRAD source code (written in Java). Simulations can be done varying the
number of runs, sample sizes, and data modalities. Performance on this
simulated data can then be compared for a number of algorithms, with parameters
varied and with performance statistics as selected, producing a publishable
report. The package presented here may also be used to compare structure
learning methods across platforms and programming languages, i.e., to compare
algorithms implemented in TETRAD with those implemented in MATLAB, Python, or
R.
label: stat
